column2: WASHINGTON, Aug. 3--Richard D. Obenshain, the Republican candidate for United States Senator in the current Virginia campaign, died late last night when his small plane crashed and burned while approaching an airport southwest of Richmond. The pilot and another occupant of the plane also were killed.

SOUTHGATE, Ky., Aug. 3--When the Campbell County grand jury reported yesterday that in five months of investigation it had found no evidence of criminal negligence in the fire that killed 165 patrons of the Beverly Hills Supper Club, and would hand down no indictments, it caught many here by surprise.
OSLO--A number of Soviet maritime violations, little noted outside Norway, have seriously strained relations between the Norwegians and the Russians, who share a short border in the Arctic.

The right of the governing council of the American Institute of Certified Public Accountants to establish a new class of membership in the organization, has been upheld in a ruling by Bentley Kassal, Justice of the New York State Supreme Court, it was disclosed yesterday.

Declaring that "the failure to learn does not bespeak the failure to teach," the Appellate Division of the Second Judicial Department yesterday rejected a $5 million educational malpractice suit against the Copiague Union Free School District.

Trans International Airlines, a charter carrier, received permission from the British Government yesterday to offer emergency service to tourists waiting in London for standby flights to the United States. Between 1,500 and 2,000 passengers are lined up for seats on Laker Airways and an other scheduled carriers.

Amid the heaviest trading in New York Stock Exchange history--65.4 million shares--the stock market started out with a surge yesterday to extend its phenomenal Wednesday advance but then pulled back sharply toward the closing bell.
WASHINGTON, Aug. 3 (Reuters)-- The House Budget Committee today approved a $490.5 billion Government spending budget with a deficit nearly $17 billion below President Carter's January plan.

CAPE TOWN, Aug. 3 (Reuters)--The Harold Robbins novel "Dreams Die First" has been banned in South Africa, the Government's Directorate of Publications announced here today. It joins the best-selling author's "The Carpetbaggers" and "The Betsy" on the list of banned books here.

IN every great permanent collection of art there is something that speaks to each of us imperiously and will not yield to the competition. Here is one critic's choice of just a few such works from six public collections in New York City.
Commodity futures traders, hopeful that credit will not be tightened further, pushed the price of interest-rate contracts sharply higher in Chicago yesterday for the second consecutive day.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 3--In an effort to repair its frayed relations with House Speaker Thomas P. O'Neill Jr., the White House announced the appointment today of his close friend and protege, Robert T. Griffin, to a newly created, $50,000-a-year Federal job.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 3--Five Southeast Asian countries opened talks with the Carter Administration today, and while the ostensible purpose was a discussion of economic issues, the accent was on political questions.
The truly prescient retailer knows what you want before you know you want it.
PARIS, Aug. 3--Two terrorists believed to be linked to Iraq murdered the Palestine Liberation Organization's chief representative and an aide here today.

Two weeks ago, Mayor Koch appealed to the 1,800 owners of tax-exempt property to make voluntary contributions to the city in lieu of taxes. So far, the city has not received a nickel, although it has got eight letters of response.

DETROIT, Aug. 3 (AP)--The Ford Motor Company will recall the first 1,475,000 automobiles and light trucks that it built in North America in the 1978 model year to correct an emission defect, the company said today.
The Seventh Avenue garment industry, which has long been relatively ineffectual in the political arena, is beginning to get somewhere in Washington, Albany and City Hall.

Beethoven's Symphony No. 9 will be performed tomorrow night at Lyndhurst in Tarrytown, N.Y., by the County Symphony of Westchester and chorus, rain or shine, at 8:30 P.M. The New England Brass Quintet will open the program at 7:30. Admission is $4 for lawn seats, $5 for tent seats. Information: (914) 631-0046.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 3--The Association of American Railroads reported today that freight traffic on United States railroads for the latest week totaled an estimated 17.3 billion ton-miles, 4.4 percent above the corresponding week a year ago.

Two weeks ago, Mayor Koch appealed to the 1,800 owners of tax-exempt property to make voluntary contributions to the city in lieu of taxes. So far, the city has not received a nickel, although it has got eight letters of response.

The postcard invitations--10,000 were sent out--read in part, "Larry Lynn's 'Let's Get Acquainted' Private Parties invites you to a special evening at New York's magnificently attractive Tavern on the Green. Wednesday Nite, Aug. 2nd, 7:30 P.M. till 1 A.M. Admission $7.00. Dress Fashionable. Invitation good for more than one."

Declaring that "the failure to learn does not bespeak the failure to teach," the Appellate Division of the Second Judi cial Department yesterday rejected a $5 million educational malpractice suit against the Copiague Union Free School District.

Coney Island, playground for a million people on hot summer weekends, was closed for public bathing at 2:30 P.M. yesterday by Parks Commissioner Gordon J. Davis, along with Brighton and Manhattan Beaches just to the east. Rockaway beaches in Queens were reopened after a one-day closing.
EAST PATCHOGUE, L.I., Aug. 3-- Vivian and Michael Mingino and their children say that they are tired of living like campers. Indeed, for them, the last several weeks have been no vacation.

OTHER cities may have more pleasant climates and saner working hours, but New York City retains its allure for lawyers. According to a placement survey, it was the most popular city for 1977 law school graduates to settle in--but just barely. Washington was close on its heels. Then came Chicago, Los Angeles, San Francisco, Philadelphia, Boston, Atlanta, Dallas and Denver.
Real-estate brokerage franchises have experienced phenomenal growth in recent years.

As the families and comrades of six dead firemen grieved and muncipal flags in New York City were lowered to halfstaff yesterday, fire officials and the firefighters union debated the handling of the Brooklyn supermarket fire on Wednesday that turned into the worst fire tragedy here since 1966.
The Metropolitan Transportation Authority was roundly criticized yesterday as incompetent, arrogant and wasteful by three city public officials and the head of a public-interest group.

New York, they say, is a summer festival. Tar bubbles in the streets under the sun. Fire hydrants send their illicit plumes of spray into an air simmering with heat and the rhythms of transistor rock. Children and dogs pant through the grilles of fire escapes high over the...

The world attendance records set by the American Contract Bridge League's Summer Nationals in Toronto last week will not be rivaled by the Summer Nationals of the American Bridge Association, a much smaller organization, which begin today in Chicago.

When an emergency call came in at 12:40 yesterday afternoon at Ladder Company 153 in Brooklyn, Lieut. Ray Jones of the Fire Department summoned his men, threw on his helmet and coat, climbed aboard a fire engine and directed the driver to the scene.
DEER LAKE, Pa., Aug. 2-- Muhammad Ali pointed his $60,000 Stutz Tomahawk up the hill this morning to what he says is his last training camp.

As long as he lived, Fred Corcoran insisted that no golfer had ever sunk a putt to win the United States Open. The championship has often been won by a single stroke, of course, and probably the last shot was always a putt, but on those occasions there were contenders still on the course who...
WASHINGTON, Aug. 3--By a vote of 4 to 1, the International Trade Commission held today that rising imports of copper have been injuring domestic producers.

MONTAGUE, Mich., Aug. 3 (UPI)-- The pesticide component C56 and seven byproducts--all produced by the Hooker Chemical Corporation--have been detected in White Lake and groundwater supplies near the plant, state officials said today.

We may yet be spared a walkout by postal workers. But a wave of strikes has recently disrupted public services in many cities. And in many others, confrontation between public employees and municipal government will be the inevitable consequence of Proposition 13 and all that. More and more Americans are being forced to consider an issue they would prefer to ignore: Should public employees have the right to strike?

THE most explosive, recordbreaking art-auction season in 200 years ended this week with both the Sotheby Parke Bernet Group and Christie, Manson Woods Ltd. surpassing all previous season totals. The London-based international ...

Carlos Chavez, the composer and conductor who for more than half a century stood in the eyes of the world for the best in Mexican music, died Wednesday in Mexico City of a heart ailment. He was 79 years old.

Jan Van Dyke and Dancers, a modern-dance troupe from Washington, will perform this weekend at the American Theater Laboratory, 219 West 19th Street, as part of a monthlong series of performances by out-oftown companies. Shows are at 8 P.M. tonight...

A group of black television producers has asked the Federal Communications Commission to investigate their charges that parts of the ABC Closeup documentary "Youth Terror: The View from Behind the Gun" were staged.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 3--Joseph A. Califano Jr., the Secretary of Health, Education and Welfare, sent letters today to each member of the Senate asking for support of his request for a special appropriation of $8.2 million to begin an influenza immunization program this fall.

NEWARK, Aug. 3--Patricia Roberts Harris, the Secretary of the Federal Department of Housing and Urban Development, described as "magnificent" today a Newark apartment complex for the elderly and pledged a new $4 million...

BOSTON, Aug. 3 (AP)--Alan H. Abrahams, the founder of the now-defunct commodity options firm of Lloyd,, Carr Co., and 11 of his former employees were indicted today by a Federal grand jury for conspiracy and mail and wire fraud.

George M. Moffett Jr., a veteran nature photographer who was also a yachtsman and the donor of a wildlife sanctuary on Martha's Vineyard, died at Lenox Hill Hospital Monday after a long illness. He was 58 years old.

WARSAW--The reconciliation begun more than a year ago between Poland's Communist leadership and the powerful Roman Catholic Church has stalled substantially short of the goals each side once envisioned.

BEAR MOUNTAIN, N.Y., Aug. 3 (UPI)--Three Queens women have been arrested on charges of assaulting two police officers assigned to the Palisades Interstate Parkway during a scuffle aboard a bus at Bear Mountain State Park, officials said today.
Bill O'Connor's wife and three children drove to the burning Waldbaum's supermarket to watch him work at the job he loved.

NEWARK, Aug. 3 (AP)--A crackdown has been ordered by Mayor Kenneth A. Gibson on city employees who allow unauthorized personnel to use municipal vehicles. He warned that any city employee who permitted an unauthorized person to drive a city car "shall be subject to the severest of disciplinary actions," and said the city would sue any private driver who became involved in an accident while at the wheel of a city car.

Plane makers in Britain, France and West Germany have agreed on terms for the British to become risk-sharing partners in building the Airbus A300 wide-body airliner, industry sources here and abroad said yesterday.

THE time is around 8:30 on a recent Friday night. The place, the Museum of Modern Art's sculpture garden, which is filled with people deployed on the chairs, the steps and around the fountains. Informal but decorous, they recline in small groups on blankets...

SALT LAKE CITY, Aug. 3 (AP)--With her husband dead of suicide, a woman and her seven children plunged 11 floors from the balcony of a downtown hotel today in an apparent act of religious zealotry, the police said. The mother and six of the children died.

PHILADELPHIA, Aug. 3 (AP)--A Federal District judge ruled today that the United States Steel Corporation had discriminated against black workers seeking management or craft positions at its suburban Fairless Works. He rejected, however, claims that blacks were routinely assigned hot, dirty jobs.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 3--The Senate Finance Committee voted today, 12 to 1, to scale down a bill that would allow parents to deduct a portion of tuition payments from the amount of Federal income taxes owed.

OTTAWA, Aug. 3--The Protestant School Board of Greater Montreal announced this week that its English-language schools had been forced to stop admitting youngsters who do not have at least one parent educated in English. Under Quebec provincial law, such pupils are required to attend Frenchlanguage schools, whether or not they want an English education.
BELFAST, Northern Ireland (AP)-- Gunmen in a passing car shot and killed a 30-year-old police reservist last night at Ballymena, 25 miles northwest of Belfast, the police reported.

NIAGARA FALLS, N.Y., Aug. 3-- Governor Carey asked President Carter tonight to declare the Love Canal area of this city a Federal disaster area and provide funds to remove 35 families and begin to clean up the site contaminated by chemical industrial wastes.

Susan Tyler Faison, a teacher at St. Ann's Episcopal School in Brooklyn Heights and a community leader in the area, died Monday of cancer at Memorial Sloan-Kettering Institute. She was 45 years old and lived at 1 Pierrepont Street in the Heights.

The much-criticized Spofford Juvenile Detention Center in the Bronx is the sort of place where signs and decorations tacked to cracked and dirty walls tell far more about its frustrated staff and young inhabitants than either group is likely to speak about directly.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 3 (AP)--The Interstate Commerce Commission today ordered the Southern Railway Company to continue running the Southern Crescent passenger train for another year between Washington and New Orleans.
WASHINGTON, Aug. 3 (AP)--The Senate today approved $4 billion for military construction but imposed deep cuts in funds for combat-readiness projects proposed for Europe.

SUNNINGDALE, England, Aug. 3 (AP)--Sally Little, a 26-year-old South African, moved to a one-stroke lead in first-round play of the European Ladies' Professional Golf Association championship today, with Laura Baugh of the United States in second place.
ATLANTIC CITY, Aug. 3--The "win" at Resorts International's gambling casino here in July was $20,652,497 for a daily average of $666,209, Resorts announced today.

LAST summer, E.L. Doctorow, author of "Ragtime" and "The Book of Daniel," put aside his new novel in progress and wrote "something." It was 12 pages long, and "I didn't know what it was," Mr. Doctorow said on the telephone from his summer home in Sag Harbor, L.I.

"I think that the physical characteristics of the Spofford Juvenile Center exhibit our schizophrenia about what Spofford is," Beverly Sanders, Assistant Commissioner of the Human Resources Administration for Special Services for...

The Boston Red Sox, who reached town in the throes of their worst slump of the season, left early today with revived spirits and batting averages after two rainy nights in Yankee Stadium--just when their three pursuers in the American League East were closing for the kill.

HACKENSACK, Aug. 3--A dispute between the opposing lawyers broke out today in the murder trial of Dr. Mario E. Jascalevich over possible evidence showing dog hairs and nonhuman blood on syringes and other items that were found in the surgeon's hospital locker.

A Tax-based Incomes Policy would tax wage increases and count on lower wage increases to result in lower price increases. Because it would act like an excise tax on labor, its effects throughout the economy would be like those of any excise tax.

Seven men believed to have been involved in at least 25 bank robberies that netted them more than $250,000 since the first of the year have been arraigned over the last three days following arrests by the Federal Bureau of Investigation.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 3--Robert Thomas Griffin, whose dismissal from the General Services Administration has severely strained White House relations with Thomas P. O'Neill Jr., the Speaker of the House, is a close ...

WASHINGTON, Aug. 3--In an effort to repair its frayed relations with House Speaker Thomas P. O'Neill Jr., the White House announced the appointment today of his close friend and protege, Robert T. Griffin, to a newly created, $50,000-a-year Federal job.
PARIS, Aug. 3--Two terrorists believed to be linked to Iraq murdered the Palestine Liberation Organization's chief representative and an aide here today.

SAN FRANCISCO, Aug. 3--Recent Government studies suggest that marijuana contaminated by paraquat is neither so prevalent nor so highly contaminated as earlier reports indicated, but one expert says the cumulative hazards of smoking the contaminated substance should not be discounted.

BANDERA, Tex., Aug. 3 (AP)--The rivers of central Texas raged over their banks today and, with at least nine persons already dead, the flooding in the hill country threatened several low-lying cities and inundated the grave site of Lyndon B. Johnson.
CHICAGO, Aug. 3--One of the world's largest and least known collections of rare American coins will be sold at auction here tomorrow night and Saturday despite a family dispute over who owns it.

DEL MAR, Calif., Aug. 3 (AP)--Bill Shoemaker, who has ridden more winners than any other jockey in the history of thoroughbred racing, was suspended yesterday by the Del Mar stewards for careless riding. Shoemaker will be sidelined for five racing days starting Saturday as the result of his disqualification aboard first-finishing Run Proud in Monday's seventh race.
ATLANTIC CITY, Aug. 3--The "win" at Resorts International's gambling casino here in July was $20,652,497 for a daily average of $666,209, Resorts announced today.

DALLAS, Aug. 3 (AP)--Vesma Grinfelds of San Francisco romped to her seventh professional women's bowling title last night in the $25,000 Metroplex open. She won $3,000 for her effort, and finished 290 pins ahead of her tour roommate, Virginia Norton of South Gate, Calif.

WHITE PLAINS, Aug. 3--A 12-yearold boy was arraigned in Westchester County Family Court today on charges of second-degree murder in the stabbing death of an 18-year-old youth last Tuesday night at a group home in South Salem, N.Y.

If the Apples are going to win their third straight World Team Tennis championship, they'll have to show a lot more than they did last night at Madison Square Garden. They were roundly defeated by the Boston Lobsters, 27-19.
Corporate demand for short-term credit may be subsiding, figures released by the Federal Reserve yesterday strongly indicated.
HAVANA, Aug 3 (Reuters)--President Fidel Castro of Cuba has renamed the island said to be the setting for Robert Louis Stevenson's "Treasure Island."

WASHINGTON--The Republican national chairman, Bill Brock, obviously understands that money is a staple of politics and that changes in the laws regulating how much money can be raised and spent in campaigns can also produce shifts in the outcome
THE publishing world this week pondered two developments in the controversial area of mergers and conglomerates: first, the plan to merge Charles Scribner's Sons and Atheneum Publishers; second, ...

TUCKERTON, N.J., Aug. 1--While you have been watching your garden grow, or whatever monopolizes your summer attention, Prof. Colin Beer has been hiding in a tiny tent on stilts in the middle of a gullery in the Atlantic Ocean watching gulls--and listening to them. He thinks they talk to each other, and he thinks he understands a lot of what they are saying.
A Baroque-music concert will be given by the Soclair Music Festival Ensemble tomorrow at 8 P.M. at the Old Red Mill of the Clinton Historical Museum Village at 56 Main Street in Clinton, N.J.

AS odd as it may seem to classify a 65-yearold landmark restaurant as a genuine "find," that is exactly how we feel about our rediscovery of Joe and Rose, the Italian steakhouse on Third Avenue between 46th and 47th Streets. Originally opened on 45th Street in 1913 by Joe and Rose Resteghini and called then Mamma...
SAN FRANCISCO, Aug. 3--A jury of six men and six women was sworn tonight in San Francisco Superior Court to try a lawsuit over a television movie alleged to have inspired a sexual assault.

The head of the fire officers association said yesterday that he did not believe there had been any delay in sounding a second alarm to save overtime payments in the Brooklyn supermarket fire that killed six firemen on Wednesday.

SAN FRANCISCO, Aug. 4--Procedural arguments today before the judge in the so-called "Born Innocent" case raised the possibility that the trial might be abruptly terminated on Monday after the newly sworn jurors hear the plaintiff's opening statement.
WASHINGTON--Helen Kelley is better prepared than most to do battle with a big bureaucracy.
RALEIGH, N.C., Aug. 4--Tobacco is more than a crop in North Carolina; it is almost a spiritual belief.

Pamela Hill, executive producer of a documentary that is the object of a complaint to the Federal Communications Commission, yesterday countercharged that a former production associate on the program had initiated the complaint because his ABC-TV contract had not been renewed.

The Bulova Watch Company, the nation's oldest watch producer, is discontinuing the manufacture of watch movements in the United States after 55 years and is shifting those operations from Queens to its plant in Switzerland.

The block on 228th Street a bit north of Linden Boulevard in Cambria Heights, Queens, has trees, grass and about 20 young people in the market for summer jobs. Not that they were in the market, but people on the block like Evelyn Paige, the Hudsons and other neighbors thought that they should be working and not idling. This is a middle-class black neighborhood and the work ethic runs deep.

MALAGA, Spain, Aug. 4 (Reuters)-- Topless sunbathing was outlawed in Spain's Costa del Sol tourist area today. The governor of Malaga Province told civil guardsmen to be "extremely vigilant" in stopping women bathers from going topless on the beaches.

Controversy over New York City's $30-million summer lunch program seems as inevitable as the heat of summer. Providing nutritious meals for school-age children evidently attracts scandal faster than the food attracts flies. Representative Fred Richmond charged last week that the program should be feeding 900,000 children, instead of only 400,000. Representative Elizabeth Holtzman has been finding mismanagement, corruption, waste and downright rotten food.

LAKE CHARLES, La., Aug. 4 (AP)-- New Federal regulations to cover liability for spills and discharges of 271 hazardous chemical wastes were thrown out today by a Federal judge who said they went beyond the scope of current law.
Deputy Mayor David W. Brown will be named Acting Mayor this month while Mayor Koch makes a five-day official visit to Paris, aides disclosed yesterday.

MINEOLA, L.I., Aug. 4--A 73-year-old retired carpenter who has been accused of being a Nazi war criminal and whom the United States is attempting to deport was shot and wounded at his home here today.
The State Department of Energy has adopted energy conservation regulations aimed at reducing the consumption of oil and electricity in the state by 5 to 6 percent by 1980.

Weeden Company, once the nation's leading third-market securities firm but recently buffeted by a series of multimillion-dollar losses, announced yesterday that it intended to "combine" with Jefferies Company, a small institutionlly oriented brokerage concern based in Los Angeles. No details of the deal were given.

NEWARK, Aug. 4--Frank D'Ascensio, the Newark City Clerk, said today that 14,810 signatures--more than twice the number needed to force a referendum --had been submitted on petitions seeking revocation of substantial pay increases voted by the City Council last month for the council, the Mayor and other high city officials.

FOREVER CHRISTIE It's always good to have a suspense play from the late Agatha Christie on the summer scene, and now "Towards Zero" has checked in for weekend performances Off Off Broadway through Aug. 20. The place is the ground-floor showcase (70 seats) of the five-year-old Academy Arts Theater Company in the Sutton East Hotel, 330 East 56th-Street, between First and Second Avenues.
The stock market finished slightly higher in much slower trading yesterday, following a day that saw the heaviest turnover in the history of the New York Stock Exchange.
Neil John Welch, the agent in charge of the Federal Bureau of Investigation's Philadelphia operations, was named yesterday as head of the New York office, the bureau's busiest office in the country.
LOS ANGELES--Here, in California, people from the East regard their past lives there as packages of experience sealed tight for the trip West.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 4--Representatives of the Association of Southeast Asian Nations said today that they enjoyed relations ranging from "satisfactory" to "good" with Communist countries in the region and received a general endorsement from the United States for this good-neighbor policy.

Summer in the city is not always a carefree time of lazy days for New Yorkers who remain here, least of all for the police to whom the season always seems to bring more trouble. The notion that crime increases in the summer is not a myth, they say, but a reality that results from increased human contact that provides a greater opportunity for violent encounters.

CAMBRIDGE, Mass., Aug. 3--Harvard University and the Central Intelligence Agency, despite a year of negotiations, are at an impasse over the university's attempt to ban secret operations and recruiting by faculty members.

MANAGUA, Nicaragua, Aug. 4 (UPI) --The Roman Catholic Church called today for the resignation of President Anastasio Somoza and the establishment of a new socio-economic order to end the long wave of violence in the country.

Someone at City Hall yesterday spent the afternoon on a giant ladder dusting off lightbulbs in the chandeliers. Others were busy scrubbing the walls, shampooing the rugs and plastering cracks in the ceiling that had not been touched up in years.
The old rah-rah is out. But a strong voice and a nimble body are still basic requirements for a high school cheerleader.

MORRISTOWN, N.J., Aug. 4--If there are rats in the belfry, their life styles may be threatened by some new neighbors who moved in last night. In fact, the rats in this Morris County community may be in serious trouble wherever they are.

OTTAWA, Aug. 4--The Ford Motor Company's decision to build a $533 million automotive engineering plant in Ontario instead of in Lima, Ohio, was welcomed by Canadians today, although some, including union leaders, expressed strong reservations about using taxpayers' money--$68 million in Canadian funds--to subsidize a company like Ford.

FIREBAUGH, Calif.--Here in the San Joaquin Valley and northward to the Sacramento Valley, it is 100 degrees and dusty--not at all the lush tropical climate generally associated with ricegrowing. Yet this is the nation's most productive rice region, its irrigated paddies producing a significant portion of the rice available for the world market.

Summer in the city is not always a carefree time of lazy days for New Yorkers who remain here, least of all for the police to whom the season always seems to bring more trouble. The notion that crime increases in the summer is not a myth, they say, but a reality that results from increased human contact that provides a greater opportunity for violent encounters.

GARDEN CITY, L.I., Aug. 4--Bob Housen, the New Jersey State amateur champion from Woodlake, Jerry Courville of Shorehaven and Bill Britton of Silver Lake were among the first-round victors today as the Metropolitan Golf Association's 76th championship continued.

Five New York City city beaches will remain closed to bathers because of oil globules in their waters, though their sands have been somewhat cleansed, and there is a scant possibility they may be opened tomorrow.

N.W. Ayer ABH International, the world's oldest advertising agency, continued to act like a spring chicken yesterday as it landed the hotly contested worldwide advertising account of Pan American World Airways. The total promotion budget is $30 million a year, with about 80 percent of that going into media.

Five New York City city beaches will remain closed to bathers because of oil globules in their waters, though their sands have been somewhat cleansed, and there is a scant possibility they may be opened tomorrow.

As the visiting Red Sox were poised to win their second game of the night at Yankee Stadium Thursday night, it began to rain heavily, and the game was suspended temporarily. Moments later, frustrated Yankee fans, already angry over their team's loss of the first game, spilled onto the field, and soon scuffles broke out between the fans and stadium security personnel.

LONDON, Aug. 4--Jeremy Thorpe, the former leader of the Liberal Party, was arrested today and charged with having conspired to murder Norman Scott, a former male model who said he had had a homosexual relationship with him.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 4 (AP)--House Speaker Thomas P. O'Neill Jr. said today that the dismissal of his friend, Robert T. Griffin, from a high Government job and his subsequent placement in a new $50,000 post had been badly handled but that "it is now a closed issue."
As the Paris couturiers looked lovingly over their shoulders to the glory days of fashion from two to four decades ago, they paid special attention to the extremities.

The Grumman Corporation, the nation's largest producer of carrier-based aircraft, yesterday reported that its second quarter-profits declined 23.6 percent from the same period in 1977. Grumman's sales increased 7.5 percent for the quarter over the same period.

MISSION VIEJO, Calif., Aug. 4 (AP) --Jim Kennedy of Knoxville, Tenn., won his second national diving title of the year, coming from third place in the final three dives last night to edge Phil Boggs and Greg Louganis in the 3-meter springboard competition of the Amateur Athletic Union outdoor diving championships.

MOSCOW, Aug. 4--Nearly $3,500 in fines and court costs were paid by a Soviet lawyer today on behalf of two American correspondents who a Moscow court had ruled were guilty of libeling Soviet television officials.

FORT MADISON, Iowa, Aug. 4 (AP)-- A propane gas line running through a parched cornfield in southeastern Iowa exploded today, killing two elderly persons, injuring six and destroying a twostory farmhouse, the authorities said. Lee County Sheriff Don Arnold identified the dead as R.C. Knight, 79 years old, and his wife, Claricy, 82.

MILWAUKEE, Aug. 4 (AP)--Sal Bando and Gorman Thomas belted two-run homers and Larry Hisle and Cecil Cooper added solo shots, powering the Milwaukee Brewers to a 6-2 victory tonight over the Boston Red Sox.

Pondering the prospect of facing Ron Guidry in just a few minutes, Earl Weaver sat in the Baltimore dugout before last night's game with the Yankees and remarked: "Our best bet is hope for four innings and then rain. They wouldn't be able to bring him back."
The dollar was mixed in world foreign exchange trading yesterday, closing strong in Europe but dipping against most currencies in New York.

RYE, N.Y., Aug. 4--The women's amateur golf team from Britain and Ireland, believing it can win the Curtis Cup for the first time in 22 years, backed up this self-confidence this morning with the best start by a British team since 1938 in the biennial series against the United States.
ALBUQUERQUE, N.M., Aug. 4-- After what was generally considered a brilliant campaign and a promising start in office last December, Mayor David Rusk is facing a movement to recall him from office.
WASHINGTON, Aug. 4 (AP)-- President Carter today signed a $4 billion farm loan bill that he said would allow some debt-ridden farmers to stay in business.
GUAYAQUIL, Ecuador, July 31--The hit American movie tune coming over the radio in one of the bamboo shacks, "Staying Alive," could not have been more ironic.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 4--The Securities and Exchange Commission today accused the Ralph M. Parsons Company, its holding corporation, the Parsons Corporation, and R.M.P. International Ltd., its Cayman Islands subsidiary, of having failed to disclose illegal payments to union officials in New Jersey, election-campaign payments in Hawaii and a questionable $6 million payment to a Middle Eastern sales consultant.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 9--The Environmental Protection Agency removed a major obstacle to completion of the nuclear power plant at Seabrook, N.H., today by rejecting arguments from environmentalists and approving the plant's open-ocean cooling system.

FAIRBANKS, Alaska--Frontiers attract go-getters. Alaska is the nation's last frontier. And so it's not really surprising that the predominant mood among the state's 400,000 citizens is what might be politely called entrepreneurial.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 4--The national unemployment rate, which tumbled in June to 5.7 percent, rebounded in July to 6.2 percent, the level that prevailed in the late winter and spring, the Bureau of Labor Statistics reported today.
TEL AVIV, Aug. 4 (Reuters)--Israel's papers appeared without news pages today because of a strike by journalists for higher salaries.

BAYREUTH, WEST GERMANY, Aug. 4--Wagner's "The Flying Dutchman," a new Bayreuth Festival production that was seen for the second time Thursday night, is an opera swept by irresistibly stormy outbursts and anchored in such stark psychological complexities that it helped start a revolution in music theater.

ALBANY, Tex., Aug. 4 (UPI)--A flash flood today sent a 20-foot wall of water over this ranching community of 2,000 people, killing six persons and forcing survivors to seek safety on roofs, trees and floating pickup trucks.

HACKENSACK, N.J., Aug. 4--A New York Times reporter went to jail here today and The New York Times Company began paying a $5,000-a-day fine after Associate Justice Thurgood Marshall of the United States Supreme Court refused to stay those penalties any longer.
OXFORD, Ohio--Successive "new Souths" proclaimed over the last 90 years have all been "media events," often in the worst sense of that expression.

BODO, Norway--Thirty-eight years ago Norwegian military men warned the country's leaders that there was an unusual amount of German naval activity off their coasts. The politicians did nothing. On April 9, 1940, the Germans pounced on Norway and quickly subdued it.
The old rah-rah is out. But a strong voice and a nimble body are still basic requirements for a high school cheerleader.

ST. LOUIS, Aug. 4.--The St. Louis Cardinals have fallen on hard times, and none has fallen harder than Bob Forsch. Tonight Forsch failed for the eighth time to record his 10th victory as the New York Mets routed the Cards, 83.

SOUTH ORANGE, N.J., Aug. 4--It has been a productive summer for Guillermo Vilas. He has finished a second book of poetry, has started a novel, written the lyrics for two songs, starred in a movie and is negotiating for a publisher for his autobiography.
LONDON, Aug. 4--A British commission has blamed Bermuda's "irregular economic structure" for the riots there last December and recommended independence for Britain's oldest colony.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 4 (AP)--Associate Justice William J. Brennan Jr. of the Supreme Court today ordered bail set at $250,000 for David Truong, a convicted spy, saying that there were not enough grounds to conclude That Mr. Truong planned to flee the country.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 4--The Environmental Protection Agency removed a major obstacle to completion of the nuclear power plant at Seabrook, N.H., today by rejecting arguments from environmentalists and approving the plant's open-ocean cooling system.

NASHVILLE, Aug. 4--Jacob F. Butcher, a "country boy banker," became the Democratic nominee for Governor early today, edging out Robert N. Clement after a seesaw vote count that was finally decided by a strong urban and black showing for Mr. Butcher.

SAN FRANCISCO, Aug. 4 (AP)-- Left-hander Vida Blue posted his 10th straight victory, and Bill Madlock's fifth-inning homer snapped a 1-1 tie that lifted the San Francisco Giants to a 2-1 victory over the Los Angeles Dodgers tonight.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 4--In the remote mountain coal fields of West Virginia, defiance of any Government regulation is a tradition. The Government bond market went through a series of sharp swings in prices yesterday, ending with small changes that nevertheless put interest rate levels substantially below where they were a week ago. WASHINGTON, Aug. 4--The national unemployment rate, which tumbled in June to 5.7 percent, rebounded in July to 6.2 percent, the level that prevailed in the late winter and spring, the Bureau of Labor Statistics reported today.

WASHINGTON A Washington engineer who has scored numerous advances in technology for government and industry has now invented a pickproof lock. Jacob Rabinow, a consultant for the National Bureau of Standards, was granted a patent this week for the key. He will receive another patent soon for the lock itself.

Race-track regulars have their version of the old joke about the brain transplant. The tout who sells victims on the idea of getting one displays a wide variety of choices: a $50,000 brain left by a successful businessman; a $100,000 specimen formerly owned by a distinguished lawyer; an even larger brain, costing $250,000, from an internationally famous scholar. Finally, the tout points to a freezer containing a tiny brain with a price tag of $500,000.

WHITE PLAINS, Aug. 7--New employees of Westchester's county government, with a few exceptions, will be required--under a law that became effective today--to be residents of the county for at least 30 days before their appointment and to continue to live in the county while they hold their jobs.

The death of a Pope brings a pause in the whirl of time, a moment to look backwards and into the future, the sort of double vision particularly appropriate at the death of the man born Giovanni Battista Montini. Pope Paul VI, as he became 15 years ago, straddled two eras, faced with the dilemma of retaining the immutable stability of the Church while pursuing the change necessary for it to survive.

ATLANTA, Aug. 7--Georgians will nominate candidates for Governor and the United States Senate and House tomorrow, with incumbents apparently firmly entrenched. The Democratic Governor, George Busbee, has five primary opponents, but polls and political observers predict a landslide victory for him.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 7--The House of Representatives approved funds tonight for another nuclear-powered carrier, contrary to President Carter's wishes, as it worked toward passage of a $119.3 billion defense appropriations bill that was described as the largest money measure ever put before Congress.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 7--Senior management executives of the Firestone Tire and Rubber Company and their attorneys are hammering out a compromise proposal under which many of its controversial Firestone 500 steel-belted radial tires would be voluntarily recalled, it was learned today.

LONDON, Aug. 7--The wealthy Thomson empire, which owns The Times of London among scores of other things, plans to move its operating base from Britain to Canada, which would allow greater opportunities to invest its profits from North Sea oil.

Although it has been under a constant barrage of criticism for years, television advertising aimed at children has generally managed to stay out of the political arena.
"Lord have mercy" echoed through St. Patrick's Cathedral yesterday as 3,500 New Yorkers crowded into a noontime memorial mass for Pope Paul VI, who died on Sunday.

The Boeing Company, the nation's largest builder of commercial aircraft, reported record earnings yesterday for the quarter ended June 30. The company, whose profit rose 37.4 percent in the second quarter from the year-earlier level, attributed the results to favorable performance on major aircraft programs and higher commercial jet transport production.

KARACHI, Pakistan, Aug. 8 (AP)-- Provincial authorities today released 33 journalists, trade union workers and students who had been held after staging a hunger strike at the Karachi Press Club during the last two weeks. During the hunger strike, the journalists' demands included reinstatement of 30 journalists arrested during an April hunger strike and withdrawal of laws restricting press freedom.

Findings of significant deterioration of Vitamin C in reconstituted frozen orange juice have prompted an inquiry by the Connecticut Department of Consumer Protection and raised the possibility of a dispute with the Florida citrus industry.

Negotiators for the pressmen's union and for the city's three major daily newspapers intensified their efforts yesterday to resolve their contract dispute over press manning and avert a strike threatened for today. The talks, which ended late last night, were scheduled to resume this morning.

The State Education Commissioner has ordered the Malverne School District on Long Island to immediately provide school transportation for about 400 children from a predominantly black area, even though the district's taxpayers have rejected financing for busing on 10 occasions.

KUALA LUMPUR, Malaysia-- Southeast Asia's largest conglomerate, Sime Darby, is on the acquisition trail. To finance its purchases, it is raising more than $200 million from the Singapore and Kuala Lumpur capital markets.

A SIGN that Broadway is getting ready for the new theatrical season has been the flurry of energetic noises--talk, song, dancers' footbeats--sounding from the studios where the musical "King of Hearts" went into rehearsal a few days ago.

TOKYO, Aug. 7 (Reuters)--Frank Weil, the United States Assistant Secretary of Commerce, warned today against expecting rapid elimination of Japan's huge trade surplus with the United States--which soared to $6.6 billion in the first half of this year, almost double the year-earlier figure.
The Del Monte Corporation's directors took a formal look yesterday at R.J. Reynolds Industries' $450 million cash offer for their company and directed management to "investigate" the bid.

At the American Bar Association convention, which will end here on Wednesday, hundreds of meetings are held, ranging from the vaguely frivolous to the practical to the serious. Attendance at these sessions in the last few days seems to have paralleled the intensity of the rain outside.

TRENTON, Aug. 7 (AP)--New Jersey's experimental project to save farmland from suburban sprawl has come to a halt--and it is unclear what state officials will do to conserve dwindling agricultural land.

Health maintenance organizations (H.M.O.'s) offer medical services for a fixed annual fee. They are cheaper than conventional, fee-for-service care because, with their income predetermined, they have no incentive to order unnecessary treatment, tests or hospitalization.
A memorial service for Edward Durell Stone, one of the nation's most eminent architects, who died Sunday, will be held at 4 P.M. tomorrow at Christ Church Methodist, 520 Park Avenue.

An American Bar Association proposal for providing Government funds to defend indigent criminals was criticized yesterday by the counsel to President Carter as an attempt by lawyers to "shirk" their ethical obligation.

JOHANNESBURG, Aug. 8 (AP)--A leading Anglican churchman in the Botswana district was released yesterday after being held in South African police headquarters since July 26, according to The Johannesburg Star. The Rev. Michael Molale, 45, was arrested at an airport in Johannesburg. He was formerly a priest in the black townships of Sharpeville and Soweto and has been active in assisting South African refugees in Botswana.

Dr. David H. Goldstein, former medical director of The New York Times and a pioneer in the development of industrial medicine, died suddenly Sunday, apparently of a heart attack, as he was returning on a bus from a visit to Boston. He was removed from the Port Authority Bus Terminal to St. Clare's Hospital.

BOSTON, Aug. 7--After a film producer received a $600,000 extortion demand, agents of the Federal Bureau of Investigation joined the Boston police in the search for three gunmen who took 13 reels of film from the office of the Brink's Productions Film Company here on July 28, a Boston official disclosed today.

SACRAMENTO, Aug. 7--A California appeals court has granted an indefinite stay of a contempt order against a Sacramento reporter who was ordered to surrender tapes and notes of conversations with a key witness in a murder case.

ROME, Aug. 7 (AP)--The Vatican has announced the following schedule of events leading up to the conclave of cardinals to elect a successor to Pope Paul VI:

SEOUL, South Korea, Aug. 7--South Korea's trade deficit with Japan surged to $1.5 billion in the first half of this year, leading Government officials and business executives to express serious concern over the widening trade gap.

The Beatrice Food Company and Tropicana Products Inc., acting 17 minutes after expiration of a Federal Appeals Court delay, announced jointly yesterday that the two companies had merged. Beatrice will now pay Tropicana stockholders some $488 million in cash and stock.
PLAINFIELD--A program designed to help people recovering from heart attacks to resume normal lives will begin a new session today at Muhlenberg Hospital here.

SAN JUAN, Puerto Rico, Aug. 7 (UPI) --An explosive device went off last night outside the auditorium where the Cuban National Ballet was performing, but there were no injuries or damage and the show went on.

ROME, Aug. 7--The Regime of the Vacant See, the interregnum between the death of a pope and the election of his successor, started formally today as Jean Cardinal Villot, the second-ranking prelate of the Roman Catholic Church, took possession of the Apostolic Palace of the Vatican.

Steel production rose to 2.64 million net tons in the week ended Aug. 5, an increase of 3.7 percent over the preceding week's 2.55 million tons, the American Iron and Steel Institute reported yesterday.

PORTLAND, Ore., Aug. 7 (AP) --The Portland Trail Blazers offered refunds today to seasonticket holders disappointed by Bill Walton's announced plans to leave the National Basketball Association team. The drive-in theater, that "passion pit" of teen-age-romance and the cheap night out for parents who could not afford a babysitter, was once heralded as the salvation of a movie industry under siege by television. Nowadays, the moviehouses are doing much better and it is the drive-in that is in need of help.

PARIS, Aug. 7 (AP)--Parisian followers of Archbishop Marcel Lefebvre, the traditionalist who challenged Pope Paul VI's leadership and reforms in the Roman Catholic Church, plan to celebrate a Mass on Thursday for the Pope's soul.

BANGKOK, Thailand, Aug. 7--Prime Minister Pham Van Dong of Vietnam told an American delegation sent to Hanoi by Senator Edward M. Kennedy that his country wanted not only a reconciliation with the United States, but also normalization of relations and "indeed friendship" between the two nations.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 7--Deploring the jailing of M.A. Farber, a New York Times reporter, Senator Daniel Patrick Moynihan said today that Congress might have to act to assure continued freedom of the press.

ALBANY, Aug. 8--The Senate's Republican leadership would endorse a plan for the state to take over the New York City's jail complex at Rikers Island if there were "written assurances" of its cost and of the city's commitment to provide alternatives for its own use, a party spokesman said today.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 8--Over the formal objections of the United States, the World Bank today approved its first loan to Vietnam. The purpose is to assist in redeveloping an agricultural area severely damaged by the war.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 8 (AP)-- Legislation that would drive up the retail price of sugar and of thousands of sugar-containing foods was approved today by the House Agriculture Committee. TOKYO, Nov. 9 (AP)--Importers reported today that they sold 3,068 imported cars in October, up 18 percent from a year earlier, but added that American cars fared poorly.
MOSCOW, Nov. 9 (UPI)--A ranking Vietnamese delegation ended an eightday state visit today and flew home with assurances of increased economic, diplomatic and military support.

Resorts International, operator of the East Coast's first legal gambling casino, announced yesterday that net earnings for the third quarter soared to $23.9 million, or $2 a share, from $1.35 million, or 14 cents a share, in the corresponding period of 1977, which included an extraordinary credit of $317,000.

MANAGUA, Nicaragua, Nov. 9 (AP)-- President Anastasio Somoza Debayle said today the United States had cut off all aid to Nicaragua and charged that "certain members" of the Carter Administration "want to ruin the reputation of my Government."

The City Council's Civil Service Committee yesterday voted out an amendment to preserve the restrictions of the employee residency law that was recently ruled unconstitutional by the State Supreme Court. The move was designed to offset possible lawsuits.

Steel produciion for the week ended Nov. 4 fell to 2.765 million tons, down 0.1 percent from the week before, the American Iron and Steel Institute reported yesterday. The industry produced 2.769 million tons the week before.

DONCASTER, England, Nov. 21 (AP) --Part of a train carrying miners to the surface of a coal pit derailed half a mile underground early today, killing 7 men and injuring 19. A spokesman for the National Coal Board said about 70 men from the night shift were riding the train when the last two of the four cars derailed. It was the first major British mining accident since 1973.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 4--The Carter Administration, armed with a draft report by the General Accounting Office, is considering major changes in a controversial law that controls wages paid to workers on Federal construction projects.

INGLEWOOD, Calif., Dec. 4 (AP)-- George Johnson's slam-dunk follow shot at the buzzer gave the New Jersey Nets a 107-105 National Basketball Association victory over the Los Angeles Lakers last night.

Three weeks ago the Mellon Bank, the largest commercial bank in Pittsburgh, became the first of many banks to offer loans to small businesses at a lower interest rate than the prime rate, which the bank charges its largest, most creditworthy corporate customers. Under the new lending structure.

Bishop Paul Moore Jr. of the Episcopal Diocese of New York, describing the Cathedral of St. John the Divine as a "symbol and rallying place in our sorely beset city," announced yesterday that, after a 37-year hiatus, construction would resume on the world's largest Gothic structure.

BOUND BROOK, N.J., Dec. 4 (UPI)-- Chemical workers at the American Cyanamid plant in this small Somerset County community struck the company last night after negotiations on a new contract broke down. The strike was called by Local III of the International Chemical Workers Union, which represents 1,300 employees at the plant.

GEORGETOWN, Guyana, Dec. 4-- Moments after she finished what is believed to be the last radio conversation with Jonestown, Sharon Amos walked briskly through the living room of the People's Temple headquarters here with a knife in her hand, witnesses said today.

CHICAGO, Dec. 4--Chicago's aldermen postponed action today on their proposed 60 percent pay increase--but not because of any embarrassment over criticism from the Carter Administration. The 50-member City Council simply put off until next week consideration of the entire 1979 budget.
SAN FRANCISCO, Dec. 4--Dianne Feinstein was selected today by fellow members of the Board of Supervisors to be the 38th Mayor of San Francisco. She will serve until the end of next year.

BECAUSE Sally Struthers and Tony Musante have done at least adequate work in other ventures, let's be charitable and place the responsibility elsewhere for their poor performances in "My Husband Is Missing," a made-for-television film that will be shown from 9 to 11 o'clock tonight on NBC-TV.

TEHERAN, Iran, Dec. 4--Renewed strikes and work stoppages by thousands of workers who oppose the Shah reportedly slashed production in Iran's oilfields by 30 percent today in a major blow to the military Government. Here in Teheran, guerrillas attacked a police station with machine guns and hand grenades, killing one policeman and wounding two.
WASHINGTON, Dec. 4--As expect ed, the Securities and Exchange Commission issued rules today to require more top corporate executives to disclose how much they are paid in sal aries and perquisites.

UP AND AT 'EM The December cover of Skyline, a monthly calendarmagazine listing exhibitions, lectures and events in architecture and design, many of them free, is an earthy reminder of its value to the many New Yorkers interested in the field.

ONE way of solving a troubled school's problems is to get rid of its troublesome students. That was precisely what happened recently when New York's Board of Education ordered the distribution of large numbers of students from Brooklyn's Boys and Girls High School among other, presumably more peaceful, schools.

MUSIC may have charms little considered even by the poets who write so much about it or the musicians who create it. Under the right circumstances, a life devoted to music may be a prescription for longevity.

AVILA BEACH, Calif., Dec. 4--Opponents of a billion-dollar nuclear power plant that is awaiting a Federal operating permit said today that scientific data had been distorted to prove that it would be safe if a major earthquake occurred.
HOLLYWOOD, Dec. 6--When "Close Encounters of the Third Kind" is re-released next year, it will include 15 or 20 minutes of film that was not in the original movie.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 5--The Supreme Court upheld today a California franchise law that allows the state to delay the opening of a new automobile dealership while deciding whether nearby dealerships will be unduly injured by the added competition.

WITH an executive order dated Sept. 7, Mayor Koch has set in motion a long-term evaluation of real property in New York City aimed at satisfying the legal requirement that all property be assessed at "100 percent of full value."

Despite a rash of seasonal television specials, the Nielsen popularity ratings this season have been dominated by regular weekly series and, as usual this season, most of them were on ABC-TV. "Laverne and Shirley," "Happy Days" and "Three's Company" were the top shows, as they have been almost every week since the season opened in September.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 5--William H. Webster, the Director of the Federal Bureau of Investigation, said today that he intended to discharge two supervisors who were involved in a series of allegedly illegal break-ins, wiretaps and mail openings in the early 1970's but would not discipline 59 other bureau employees, most of them street agents, who were also involved.
CHARLOTTESVILLE, Va.--Presidential government is now almost half a century old, and it is in trouble.
GEORGETOWN, Guyana, Dec. 5--The Guyanese Government sought tonight to refute charges that it had given special treatment to the Rev. Jim Jones and his followers in the People's Temple.
William Grant Still, dean of black classical composers, died Sunday in a nursing home in Los Angeles. He was 83 years old.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 5--The Treasury, announcing certain details of its first public offering in a foreign credit market in history, said today that on Dec. 12 it would begin selling to German residents three-year and fouryear notes denominated in marks worth the equivalent of $1.5 billion.

OSSINING, N.Y.--Bernard Rome, president of the New York City Offtrack Betting Corporation, has proposed that the State Legislature abolish the New York Racing Association and entrust Belmont Park, Saratoga and Aqueduct to a public authority. He has attacked one of the last bastions of feudal privilege--and none too soon.

VATICAN CITY, Dec. 5 (Reuters)-- Pope John Paul II received Andrew young, the chief American delegate to the United Nations, in a private audience today, Vatican officials said. No details were disclosed.

N.J., Dec. 5 --By late morning, the luckiest deer hunters had emerged from the wet woodlands of the Great Swamp National Wildlife Refuge and were converging on the weighing station outside the small olive-drab barn. WASHINGTON, Dec. 5--Gen. George S. Brown, a four-star Air Force general who retired last June as chairman of the Joint Chiefs of Staff, died at a hospital here today of cancer of the prostate. He was 60 years old.

Boeing, International Business Machines and other glamour issues led the stock market sharply higher yesterday on increased trading volume. The Dow Jones industrial average advanced more than 13 points.

A heavy volume of new tax-exempt state and city bond issues was marketed yesterday as this week's $1.1 billion schedule of financing hit full stride. WASHINGTON, Dec. 5--Earlier this month Carter Administration aides disclosed that the United States was about to embark on a new drive to save as many as 140 million American lives in the event of a major nuclear war. The disclosure stirred considerable skepticism, even disbelief, in many circles. Observers asked why, after civil defense was essentially abandoned 15 years ago, President Carter had decided to revive it.

Denmark is the latest member of the Atlantic alliance to register alarm over the boldness of the steadily expanding Warsaw Pact forces in its area.

ALBANY, Dec. 5--Staff negotiators for Governor Carey and the legislative leaders reached agreement tonight on a bill to increase interest rates on home mortgages and attempt to halt redlining, discrimination by banks against particular areas.

CAIRO, Dec. 5--The Foreign Ministry issued a statement tonight condemning Israel for demolishing Arab houses on the West Bank of the Jordan. It said such actions were "terrorist" measures that undermined Middle East peace efforts.

MEXICO CITY, Dec. 5 (AP)--Mexico's national consumer price index rose 1 percent in November because of rising food prices and rents in Mexico City, the Bank of Mexico said today. The index has risen 15.2 percent this year, an average of 1.3 percent a month. Mexico City's wholesale price index rose 1.3 percent in November, the bank said.

DETROIT, Dec. 5--The sale of new American-made cars in the final 10 days of November rose 4 percent above the level of the corresponding period a year ago, the nation's four major automobile manufacturers reported today. However, as was the case in the previous sales period, the benefits of the gain were felt only by the General Motors Corporation.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 5--A new scholarship that will allow hundreds of young people from developing nations to study in the United States was initiated today as a memorial to the late Senator Hubert H. Humphrey.

ALBANY, Dec. 5--The retiring New York State Comptroller, Arthur Levitt, announced today that his office would begin using a new accounting method intended to make it far more difficult for a governor to disguise the fiscal manipulations that have become a standard part of state budgeting.

A Federal judge yesterday denied fees for a Federal trustee and two law firms and ordered them to return allowances received in connection with the bankruptcy of Arlan's Department Stores, a New England discount chair liquidated in 1975.

WASHINGTON, Wednesday, Dec. 6 (AP)--A United States official discounted as a "psychological ploy" a threat last summer by members of the People's Temple that they would commit mass suicide if their leader, the Rev. Jim Jones, should lose a child custody suit, Federal officials said last night.

TOKYO, Dec. 5--After more than 12 months of tough bargaining aimed at increasing Japanese imports of American citrus fruit and beef products, the United States and Japan reached final agreement today liberalizing ground rules governing their 54 billion annual bilateral farm trade.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 5--George W. Ball, who was an Under Secretary of State in the Kennedy and Johnson Administrations, has been asked by President Carter to lead an interagency study on American policy options in the Persian Gulf. White House officials said today.

Twentieth-century British chamber music, including works by Elizabeth Maconchy, William Allwyn, John Ireland and John Addison, will be performed tonight at 8 P.M. in the Hunter College Playhouse, East 68th Street, between Park and Lexington Avenues.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 14 (AP)--Ben H. Bagdikian, a writer and frequent press critic, proposed today that a limit be placed on the ownership of newspapers by large corporations to restrict their control over the industry.

MOUNT HOLLY, N.J., Dec. 14-- Five jockeys and two trainers accused of fixing horse races at Garden State Park four years ago were found guilty tonight after a 10-week trial based largely on testimony supplied by Anthony (Big Tony) Ciulla. Two other defendants, a jockey and a trainer, were acquitted by a Burlington County jury in State Superior Court.

SAN DIEGO, Dec. 14--Pacific Southwest Airlines won the first round in a proxy fight with Dallas-based Valhi Inc. The dispute is over adoption of corporate amendments proposed by the management of Pacific Southwest. The amendments are designed to make the nations 12th-largest airline less vulnerable as a takeover target.
"Family Jam '78," a 10-day festival for the entire family, with drama, dance, music, magic and mime, will begin today at the Entermedia Theater, 189 Second Avenue (12th Street).

MADRID, Dec. 14 (Reuters)--Salvador de Madariaga, the Spanish author and diplomat, died of a heart disease today in Locarno, Switzerland, a spokesman for the Royal Household here said. Mr. de Madariaga, who was ambassador in Washington in 1931, was 92 years old.

"THE audience told me what it wanted in 'The Brink's Job,'" William Friedkin, the director, was saying the other day. "I know because I previewed it. That's something I didn't do with 'The Exorcist' or 'The French Connection' or any other picture I've made.
CAIRO, Dec. 14--President Anwar elSadat said tonight that he was still confident that a peace treaty with Israel would be signed.

IN an enlightened world, public disgrace normally brings stardom with a cluster of media contracts, speaking engagements and the like. But to Bernard Reis, a defendant in the Rothko trial, it brought only ruin of the old-fashioned kind, with bankruptcy and the loss of many friends. And, when the 83-year-old accountant died, he was characterized in the obituaries simply as a former executor of the Rothko estate, his passing reported perfunctorily.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 14--In a civil complaint filed today in Federal court, the Securities and Exchange Commission said that bank holding companies must disclose to shareholders significant violations of banking law or "unsafe and unsound" practices cited in traditionally secret bank examination reports.
A printing press concern, R. Hoe Company, which was forced into receivership by its creditors in 1969, finally emerged from bank ruptcy last spring--as a manufacturer of saw blades.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 14--The Environmental Protection Agency proposed today far-reaching new rules that for the first time would require producers of hazardous waste materials that pose a threat to human health to dispose of them in a safe and approved manner.

WHEN B. Dalton, the giant book chain opened its Fifth Avenue store last month, it pledged its first day's pro ceeds to the New York Public Library. Last Monday Dalton made good its pledge to the tune of $15,189.93. But the book merchandiser went much, much further. It also presented the library through the Dayton Hudson Foundation ...

Dr. Fager was an extraordinary race horse who, at the age of 4, brought off an unprecedented sweep. He was the first in American racing to win four national championships in a single year--horse of the year, handicap champion, sprint champion, grass champion.

The Hearst Corporation has announced it has entered into agreements to purchase for an undisclosed amount two Texas daily newspapers--The Midland Reporter-Telegram and The Plainview Daily Herald. Both newspapers are published afternoons and Sundays. The Midland Reporter-Herald has circulations of 21,000 daily and 23,000 Sunday, while The Plainview Daily Herald is a 10,000 daily and Sunday newspaper.
The former wife of an heir to the Dodge Motor Company fortune was indicted in Manhattan yesterday on charges of looting $390,000 from her 24-year-old son's trust fund.

The Colony Ticket Service of Union City, N.J., has agreed to turn over to the Metropolitan Museum of Art all the tickets to the "Treasures of Tutankhamen" exhibition it has and not to distribute any tickets to the exhibition.
Connie Jackson had Blue Cross and Blue Shield and major medical insurance, but the medicals bills for her daughter's asthma were so costly that she filed for bankruptcy.

THE interchange between Broadway and New York's cabaret circuit is a fruitful one; so fruitful, in fact, that it's hard to believe that cabaret could exist here on its present scale without a restless pool of Broadway actors with solo ambitions to feed it.
QUEBEC, Dec. 14--The Quebec government announced tonight that it would expropriate control of Asbestos Corporation from the General Dynamics Corporation of St. Louis.

FOR a while, as "Ballroom" introduces its characters, its situation, an initial pair of songs and a few dances, it keeps to an oddly subdued tempo, interesting in its unexpectedness. Nothing very exciting or witty or beautiful happens in the first half hour of this musical about old people finding love at a golden-age ballroom; but it is tasteful and unforced.

The shadow of Balenciaga hovers over the Halston collection. Halston denies it, of course. "Maybe in the big dresses," he admits grudgingly, referring to, among other things, a perfectly proportioned halter-neck black style, its full skirt elevated in front and dipping to the floor at back.

Mayor Koch yesterday awarded a $25.6 million contract for 1979 construction work and maintenance on the Third Water Tunnel, the $420 million project that has been virtually halted since 1975 in a dispute on costs.
WASHINGTON, Dec. 14 (AP)-- The Business Council's economic consultants expect real economic growth next year of 2 to 3 percent with an inflation rate of 7.5 to 8 percent.
JERUSALEM, Dec. 14--Secretary of State Cyrus R. Vance made a brief visit to Bethlehem in the occupied West Bank before leaving for Egypt today.
For New York bridge enthusiasts and many further afield, the 1978 tournament year reaches its climax at the New York Hilton Hotel with the Winter Regional Championships beginning today.

CLEVELAND, Ohio, Dec. 14--This once-thriving industrial city moved to the brink of fiscal default today. City officials failed to reach a consensus on how to pay off $15.5 million in short-term loans due by the close of business tomorrow, and a major lender notified the city late today of its objections to the Mayor's proposals to prevent default.

PROGRAM notes can make a difference. Anyone who saw Liz Pasquale's "Littler and Littler" without reading the program notes might have been mystified by what went on. For this work, performed Wednesday night at the Third Street Music School by the Amazing Shrinking Dance Company, looked like nothing more than a miscellaneous collection of scenes.
BOSTON, Dec. 14 (AP)--John Wensink scored his 18th and 19th goals tonight to power the Boston Bruins to a 52 victory over the Washington Capitals.

SALISBURY, Rhodesia--One of the few things on which each group in Rhodesia's spreading guerrilla war agrees is that the United States could and should bring a quick settlement--by helping its side win.

"Romance is coming back," Barbara Tober said happily as Jerry Kravat and the Waldorf Astoria orchestra struck up a Strauss waltz. Then Mrs. Tober delightedly added, "Ball dresses are coming back! Debutante parties are coming back! Proms are coming back! We're going into a very romantic era. Discos may be popular, but the thrust is definitely toward romance."

Students in the seventh-grade social studies classes of the Lawrence Junior High School on Long Island began a "rent a pen" service in 1970, through which forgetful students can borrow pens for a penny per classroom period. As a result, contributions of $813.64 have been received by The New York Times Neediest Cases Fund.

IT promised to be a big night at the Metropolitan Opera. Shirley Verrett was singing the title part in "Tosca" on Wednesday night with Luciano Pavarotti as Cavaradossi, both of them trying on those roles for the first time in that house.

The tax-exempt bond market, emerging from its steepest decline in four months, appeared to stabilize yesterday as Pennsylvania and Rhode Island sold major bond issues that carried yields high enough to attract investors.

MONTEGO BAY, Jamaica, Dec. 14 (UPI)--Ilie Nastase evened his record at one victory and one loss today in the World Championship of Tennis challenge cup competition with a 6-5, 6-4 victory over Dick Stockton.
There will be a pro football doubleheader on television tomorrow, with the second game matching two playoff teams, Pittsburgh and Denver (Channel 4, 4 P.M.).

Officials of both men's and women's college athletic programs remained confused about Title IX regulations a week after the Secretary of Health, Education and Welfare attempted to clarify the issue by announcing proposed guidelines for compliance with the Federal law banning sex discrimination in intercollegiate athletics.

According to Gil Clancy, the Madison Square Garden matchmaker, Gerald Cooney is "the best young heavyweight prospect in the world." Clancy based his assessment on the fact that the managers of at least 22 other heavyweights turned down an eight-round match against Cooney.

BUCHAREST, Rumania, Dec. 11-- Bread shortages have caused lines to form in front of bake shops of late for the first time in years, and taxi drivers are being restricted to four gallons of gasoline a day.
LONDON, Dec. 14--Prime Minister James Callaghan's Government survived a vote of confidence tonight and staved off a winter election.

MONTREAL, Dec. 14--Two former members of an underground group known as the Quebec Liberation Front, who have voluntarily ended an eight-year exile, reserved their plea today after being formally charged with the kidnapping of a British official in October 1970.

The Massachusetts Banking Department announced yesterday that it was putting out the first shoppers' guide to residential mortgage rates by a state banking agency, adding that its study showed mortgage rates in Massachusetts ranged from 9 to 12.5 percent.

PRINCETON, N.J., Dec. 14--John Lewis, a senior guard, scored 10 points in the second half, including four free throws in the final minute, as Princeton rallied from a 13-point deficit and defeated Fordham, 38-37, tonight.

MOST people who were watching the Saturday Night Live television program last weekend must have been nonplussed by the musical guest, Kate Bush. The musical slot on this show has become perhaps the most sought-after, prestigious showcase in the nation, and here was a young woman whom hardly anybody in America could have heard of, let alone heard.

Under pressure from Mayor Koch and other political figures, Bronx Democrats have decided to open up the process of selecting an interim successor to Borough President Robert Abrams, who is to be sworn in as State Attorney General on Jan. 1.

HONG KONG, Dec. 14--Vietnamese forces have moved as far as 70 miles into southern Cambodia, putting them in position to cut Highway 4, linking Phnom Penh to its main port, Western analysts said today.

OSLO, Dec. 14 (AP)--After only nine months of state ownership, Tandberg Radio and Television of Norway, once the flagship of the country's electronics industry, has been declared bankrupt and was placed under court administration today.

THE exhibition that opened this week at the Whitney Museum of American Art under the title, "William Carlos Williams and the American Scene, 1920-1940," is an unusual event. It is an art exhibition based on the career of a writer. On its walls, therefore, are almost as many words to read as there are pictures to look at. Fortunately, the words are mostly those of a highly accomplished poet.
The performance of New Jersey judges will be formally rated under a "report card" system that is expected to start in the next few months.
SALLY GROSS performs infrequently. On Wednesday at Hunter College Studio Theater she presented six new and old solos. They were, on the whole, well worth the wait.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 14--For M.O. Lee, chairman of the VF Corporation, a women's wear manufacturer in Reading, Pa., the opportunity was too good to resist. President Carter had written to him and the other heads of the nation's 500 top industrial companies asking them to pledge to comply with the Administration's voluntary price and pay standards.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 14--The Department of Justice maintained today that a small West Coast union had no legal right to challenge President Carter's anti-inflation program of voluntary wage and price guidelines.

If we may borrow a little something from astrology, this is the time of year when Money finds itself in the House of Christmas, Greed is on the cusp of Grasp, and Giving is in close conjunction with Taking. Herewith, then, a few star-crossed incidents from around town.
Philip L. Toia, the Deputy Mayor for Financial Management, said yesterday that "some municipal hospital closings are inevitable" if New York is to survive its current fiscal crisis.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 14--Chief Justice Warren E. Burger suggested today that a new Supreme Court position, that of "circuit justice for administration," be created to relieve him of administrative duties that he described as increasingly burdensome.

SAN FRANCISCO, Dec. 14--The United States Steel Corporation has been charged with antitrust violations by a California manufacturer of metal ends for fiber motor-oil cans. Merit Ends Inc. charges that "U.S. Steel has employed its superior economic power and leverage to unreasonably restrain trade and substantially lessen competition."

ALTHOUGH the weekend schedule is crowded with specials, tonight's outstanding presentation is a standard made-for-television movie. On ABC at 9, "Long Journey Back" is "inspired" by the true story of a high-school girl who loses a leg and her memory in a school-bus accident and how her family handles her recovery.
In an effort to marshal support for sweeping proposals to alter the Civil Service, Mayor Koch has invited 60 mayors from all parts of New York State to a briefing at City Hall this afternoon.
JERUSALEM, Dec. 14--Prime Minister Menachem Begin said today that he had called a special Cabinet meeting to discuss the stalemate in negotiations for a peace treaty with Egypt.

Suffolk County officials reported yesterday that they had new evidence of structural flaws so serious that they might require replacing the main pipe to the treatment plant of the county's controversial Southwest Sewer District system.

If Van Cliburn became music's most celebrated competition winner 20 years ago, Youri Egorov, the Russian-born pianist who makes his Carnegie Hall debut at 8 P.M. tomorrow night, may well have become its most celebrated loser.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 14--Expressing acute frustration over the latest snag in Israeli-Egyptian peace negotiations, President Carter said today that it now was up to Israel to accept or reject the projected treaty.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 14--Amid mounting Congressional skepticism over the Carter Administration's spending plans for the coming fiscal year, the President said tonight that he would stand by his commitment to raise the defence budget by approximately 3 percent.

The Earl of Snowdon, married from 1960 until this year to Britain's Princess Margaret, will make Lucy Lindsay-Hogg his countess today in London. Antony Armstrong-Jones, you may recall, was court photographer at the time of his royal marriage and elevation to the title.

LUSAKA, Zambia, Dec. 14 (Reuters) --Kenneth D. Kaunda was assured today of a fourth term as Zambia's President, maintaining the dominant position he has held in the nation's political life since independence from Britain 14 years ago.

DETROIT, Dec. 14 (AP)--The American Motors Corporation, whose new Spirit subcompact has failed to halt the company's sales slump, said today that it would cut prices on all three Spirit models by $200, as much as 5.1 percent.

WASHINGTON (AP)--The Government today authorized widespread use of a graduated monthly home loan payment plan that permits lower mortgage payments during the first few years a home buyer owns a house.

SYDNEY, Australia, Dec. 14-- American and Australian negotiators have agreed to let Continental Air Lines fly between the West Coast of the United States and Australia. They have also agreed to cut some fares sharply.
