Kennedy in 1928 and the day it was sold to Lucille Ball and Desi Arnaz in 1958. The show began last night, and on today's bill is "Rio Rita" (1929) at 2:30.
Two letters, one from Bridgeport, Conn., the other from West 48th Street here in New York, carried the same message yesterday to the 67th annual appeal of The New York Times Neediest Cases Fund.

ST. PAUL, Dec. 21 (AP)--Roger C. Hennings, a former judge, has been sentenced to up to 10 years in prison for swindling almost $500,000 from elderly clients, a church organization and two banks. He was sentenced yesterday in Ramsey County District Court on four counts of grand theft. Once a Municipal Court judge in surburbun Maplewood, he formerly practiced law in St. Paul.

JACKIE aud Liz, Marilyn and Mao: they are all riding again, along with Campbell's Soup and the electric chair. In other words, some of the images chosen by Andy Warhol during the period 1960 to 1973 are being paraded in their original form at the Blum Helmann Gallery (13 East 75th Street). Numbering 12 canvasses in all, the show is an invitation to reflect, yet again, on the confusion...

WASHINGTON, Dec. 21.--With a warning that New York City "does not have the resources" to close its budget gap by itself, Mayor Koch formally called on President Carter today to "fulfill the commitments that we feel were made" to increase Federal aid this year and next.
After a session punctuated by catcalls, hisses, cheers and boos, the city's Board of Estimate approved a resolution yester day evening condemning the Westway highway project.
WASHINGTON, Dec. 21--The chairman of the Interstate Commerce Commission rejected today demands by two House committee chairmen that the agency stop its moves to deregulate the trucking industry.

THE concept of a jazz-rock group as a section of jazz horns over a rock rhythm section that started 10 years ago with Blood, Sweat and Tears has worn thin since then. But one group that still has faith in the formula is Cosmology, a six-piece ensemble that has been around for six years and that was at Seventh Avenue South, Seventh Avenue at Leroy Street, on Tuesday and Wednesday.

EVER since Max Ernst made the discovery nearly 60 years ago that old engravings from 19thcentury magazines and commercial catalogues could be effectively transformed through the medium of collage into mysterious symbols of the irrational, the way has been open for artists to employ every sort of printed pictorial matter--regardless how commonplace--for the creation of a private iconography.

UNITED NATIONS, N.Y., Dec. 21-- The General Assembly asked the Security Council today to meet to consider sanctions against South Africa for not agreeing to a United Nations plan for supervised elections in South-West Africa.

However, the Justice Department appears likely to continue with its efforts to stymie the deal.

Saul P. Steinberg, chairman and president of the Reliance Group Inc., and Laura Bordoni Sconocchia were married Wednesday. Rabbi Irving Hiat performed the ceremony at the Park Avenue apartment the couple will occupy.

WALKER, Mich., Dec. 21 (AP)-- The Walker police said today they would no longer patrol International Hockey League home games of the Grand Rapids Owls because the safety of the police was jeopardized by management-inspired rowdiness.

CROSSMAGLEN, Northern Ireland, Dec. 21 (Reuters)--Three British soldiers were shot to death today on the main street of this border village. It was the worst attack against British forces in the province in nearly three years.

QUM, Iran, Dec. 19--Iran is a country of two worlds that are locked in a battle for supremacy.

Neither Bob Griese of the Miami Dolphins nor Dan Pastorini of the Houston Oilers has been practicing this week because of injuries and both were listed yesterday by the National Football League as "questionable" performers for Sunday's playoff game at Miami.

Shirley Baig will succeed Raphael Paganelli as manager of NYT Pictures, it was announced yesterday by Rob Roy Buckingham, editor and general manager of The New York Times News Service. Mr. Paganelli recently became deputy picture editor of The Times.

The Empire Savings Bank, a New York mutual savings bank with 10 branches and assets of $715 million, has not had a chairman for a decade. But, effective Jan. 1, the bank will have one.

What makes the operettas of Gilbert and Sullivan forever popular? Norman Meadmore, founder-director of the London Savoyards, believes that they are "the only thing in the theater today to which you can take your aunt or grandmother or young daughter without being embarrassed."

WARSAW, Dec. 21 (AP)--The Communist authorities censored Pope John Paul's Christmas message to his home diocese of Cracow, cutting out all references to Poland's patron, St. Stanislaus, a newspaper editor said today. A separate papal message to the entire nation was printed in full by the Cracow Catholic weekly.
The dollar rose against most major currencies in foreign-exchange trading in Japan, Europe and New York yester day, but trading was light because of the nearness of the Christmas holiday.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 21--The House Select Committee on Assassinations has received additional evidence that four shots were fired at President Kennedy in Dallas 15 years ago, reopening the debate over whether he was attacked by one or two assassins, committee sources said today.

NEWARK, Dec. 21--A coalition of municipal unions today voted to call a general work stoppage in the city unless Mayor Kenneth A. Gibson rescinded layoff notices to more than 1,400 municipal and school employees.

If they do their job too well, get rid of them. That appears to be Governor Carey's prescription for handling environmental officials who try to enforce the law. The Governor is urging the White House to fire the regional administrator for the Federal Environmental Protection Agency, Eckardt C. Beck. And soon, aides say, he will ask the state's environmental commissioner, Peter A.A. Berle, to resign.
South Africa's mineral wealth verges on the fabulous. But that resource is not likely to be enough to avoid serious political trouble stemming from a weakening economy.

SAN FRANCISCO, Dec. 21--Terri Buford, until two months ago a top aide to the Rev. Jim Jones, told reporters today that every violent, illegal or "reprehensible" act that he or members of his Peoples Temple undertook had been initiated or approved by Timothy O. Stoen. Mr. Stoen, once a prosecutor here, was the chief legal adviser to Mr. Jones before resigning from the sect two years ago.

Federal authorities have called him a "James Bond" character. A biographer says he is a "brigand from another era." Henry A. Grunwald, the former managing editor of Time magazine, will become Time Inc.'s top editorial officer, editor in chief, when Hedley Donovan, who currently holds the title, retires at the age of 65 on June 1, 1979.

CABLE, Wis., Dec. 21--On a subfreezing, overcast afternoon, Norway got the jump on its international rivals in the season's first World Cup men's cross-country skiing event by placing two of its runners in the first three places at Mount Telemark.

PARIS, Dec. 21--Greece completed the details of its entry into the European Economic Community today, agreeing on terms for full membership with the nine present member states in an accord that has far-reaching economic and political implications for Western Europe.

Two brokers were convicted in Manhattan yesterday on Federal charges of conspiracy to defraud the Government by creating $27 million in fraudulent tax losses from 1974 to 1976. The fraud involved rigged trading of commodities and manipulation of prices on the cruae oil futures market of the New York Cotton Exchange.

DETROIT, Dec. 21 (UPI)-- After six weeks as president of the Chrysler Corporation, Lee A. Iacocca says the beleaguered No. 3 auto company is suffering from discipline problems, but he expects to turn it around with tough leadership.

HAMPTON, N.H., Dec. 21 (UPI)-- Five members of the antinuclear Clamshell Alliance were sentenced yesterday to 60 days in jail and were fined $200 each in connection with demonstrations Sept. 23 and Nov. 11 at the Seabrook nuclear power plant. The five men, who were charged with criminal trespass, were released on $100 bail each, pending an appeal.

CORRALEJO, Canary Islands, Dec. 21 (AP)--A ferry with 32 persons aboard sank in heavy seas during the night after breaking apart on the rocks off Fuerteventura, one of the Canary Islands, and 12 persons were drowned or are missing, the Spanish Navy said today. The ferry was carrying 30 German passengers and two Spanish crewmen.

SALEM, Ore., Dec. 21--Greta Rideout, whose husband is on trial here for raping and beating her, boasted to her neighbors shortly after her husband was arrested that she was "going to become rich and famous," three witnesses testified today.

ROSEAU, Dominica, Dec. 21 (UPI)-- The parliament of this new Caribbean island nation elected its speaker, Fred DeGazon, as the first president of the republic today. Mr. DeGazon, candidate of the Dominica Labor Party of Prime Minister Patrick John, won with 16 votes in the House of Assembly, against 10 for John Bully, candidate of the opposition Dominica Freedom Party. Dominica became independent of Britain Nov. 3.

ALTHOUGH one might not consider the Upper West Side a likely locale for a restaurant that is romantic, charming and elegant, that is exactly what is to be found on the corner of 119th Street and Morningside Drive, at the Terrace Restaurant atop the Columbia University residence, Butler Hall.

A committee of professional theater people and noted admirers of the plays of Eugene O'Neill has been formed to mount annual observances in his honor, culminating in 1988 in nationwide celebrations of the hundredth anniversary of his birth, on Oct. 16.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 21--The White House announced today that Deputy Secretary of State Warren M. Christopher would lead a high-level mission to Taipei next week to discuss a framework for unofficial relations between the United States and Taiwan after Jan. 1.
NEW DELHI, Dec. 21--Supporters of former Prime Minister Indira Gandhi continued to stage violent demonstrations in several parts of India today, demanding that she be released from prison.
STATELY, cash-plump International Business Machines jollied up Wall Street at least for a while this week with its decision to split its expensive stock 4 for 1.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 21 (AP)--The Energy Department denied today a proposal to import large amounts of liquefied natural gas from Algeria through a planned terminal on the Texas Gulf Coast.

GEORGETOWN, Guyana, Dec. 21--A preliminary inquiry into the slaying of Representative Leo J. Ryan and four other Americans made little headway today as prosecution efforts to prove a conspiracy faltered. Only two witnesses were heard and the prosecution initially failed to show up.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 21--Alfred E. Kahn, head of the President's antiinflation program, suggested today that taxes on unleaded gasoline be cut and taxes on leaded gasoline be increased as the Administration continued to reassess its oil policy.
Howard Schmertz, director of the Millrose Games, stopped by Glenn Cunningham's table in the Penn Plaza Club in Madison Square Garden. "How many races did you win in the Garden?" he asked.

The Dictaphone Corporation announced early yesterday that its board of directors had approved the offer by Pitney-Bowes Inc. to acquire Dictaphone. The transaction, involving cash and securities, is valued at about $131 million.

The Dictaphone Corporation, jumping more than 5 points, was the latest winner yesterday in Wall Street's surging list of corporate takeovers. It ranked as one of the few big gainers in a session that generally showed modest price changes.
IT'S time again for the 10-bestrecords list, and not a moment too soon for last-minute Christmas shopping. But caveat emptor: as usual, subjectivity is the criterion.

SYDNEY, Australia, Dec. 21 (AP)-- Alan Stone of Australia, a part-time performer on the pro circuit, upset third-seeded Arthur Ashe, 6-2, 3-6, 6-3, today and moved into the men's quarterfinals of the $175,000 New South Wales tennis tournament.

GENEVA, Dec. 21--Secretary of State Cyrus R. Vance and Foreign Minister Andrei A. Gromyko said today that they had made progress in their first day of discussions toward resolving the issues holding up a new treaty on the limitation of strategic arms, but they also said that some difficult problems remained.

A year after Gloria and Mike Stivic elected to leave Archie Bunker's blue-collar nest, Archie's wife, Edith, has decided to follow their example. As a result, "All In the Family," one of the most popular shows on television since 1971, is likely to drop out of the CBS schedule next fall.

BRIDGEPORT, Conn., Dec. 21--This struggling city's application for a $2.5 million Federal loan to help build a huge amusement park-restaurant-market complex has been turned down by the Department of Housing and Urban Development, and the Mayor responded today by characterizing the agency's position with a vulgarism and said the application would be resubmitted next month.

"ABROADWAY MUSICAL" was designed as a Broadway musical about the making of a Broadway musical. The originator and the co-producer of the show, Norman Kean, has apparently experienced many of the typical tribulations of the genre--false starts, hirings, firings, rewritings on the road.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 21 (AP)--A sign of possible weakness in the economy emerged today in the Government's report that orders for major factory goods declined in November for the first time in four months.
The growth of the nation's basic money supply slowed for the third consecutive week, decelerating to an annual rate of 6.7 percent--the lowest since early April.

CABLE television, with only about a 20 percont penetration of American households, is already a viable national advertising medium without having a negative impact on broadcast TV, Young Rubicam said yesterday.

TOKYO, Dec. 21 (AP)--The Toshiba Corporation, one of Japan's largest manufacturers of consumer electronics equipment, said today that it had halted exports of color television sets to the United States because of high import duties and the yen's rise against the dollar.

SAN JUAN, Puerto Rico, Dec. 21 (AP)--A barge oil spill, already af fecting beaches along Puerto Rico's northeast coast, now threatens another tourist area on the island, a Coast Guard spokesman said today.
TEHERAN, Iran, Dec. 21 (Reuters)-- A new threat to the Shah's military Government was headed off today by a surprise move to adjourn Parliament and delay a censure debate.

TAIPEI, Taiwan, Dec. 21--Dead silence reigned in Taipei's big municipal stadium, save for the thud, thud, thud of feet hitting the ground as Y.C. Wang and his aides circled the track in almost complete darkness.

CAIRO, Dec. 21--Senior Egyptian officials contended today that Israel, not Egypt, had caused the present deadlock over a peace treaty by reneging on understandings reached earlier by the two countries.

SANA, Yemen, Dec. 21 (Reuters)-- China will extend technical aid to Yemen to build a $20 million international conference hall just outside Sana, under an agreement approved by the Council of Ministers yesterday. China has built several highways in the country as well as a textile mill.

One of the biggest scores ever recorded in a New York regional championship was posted here a week ago by Kitty Bethe and Karen McCallum, both of New York. They captured the women's pair title at the New York Hilton Hotel with a score of 435 match points, equivalent to almost 70 percent.

GIRARDVILLE, Pa., Dec. 21-- Here, on a windy corner of a narrow street, there stands an aged tavern where people of Irish stock take shelter from the cold. It is called Wayne's, and it is the kind of place where old men remember, with startling authenticity, things that did not happen, and old women refuse a shot of whiskey, for the sake of propriety, but drink enough beer to float a skiff.

The number of occupied apartment buildings falling under city ownership because of landlord abandonment or tax defaults, already up sharply, is expected to triple over the next 18 months, city officials say.

But in New York these days she's the razzle-dazzle ice skater with the smile that won't quit, the one who signs her autograph by drawing a fivepointed star and a dollar sign (Starbuck, get it?), the one who almost steals John Curry's "Ice Dancing" show from John Curry himself.

Expressing skepticism over an announcement that $1.1 million in gold was missing from a Federal facility in New York City, officials on Wall Street and in the private precious-metal industry sug gested yesterday that faulty arithmetic by the Treasury Department, rather than thefts by its employees, might account for the reported loss.
Rose Marie Reid, the bathing suit designer, died Monday at her home in Provo, Utah, of complications after surgery. She was 66 years old.

MOSCOW, Dec. 21--The Soviet Union, in an unusual step, made public today details of Tuesday's personal message from Leonid I. Brezhnev to President Carter in an apparent effort to show that the Soviet leader did have questions about the new Chinese-American relationship and would watch it closely.

Gable Industries said yesterday that its shareholders would vote Dec. 27 on a proposal to change the corporate name to the Hajoca Corporation, which is the name of the largest of three Gable operating units.

The Paper Bag Players, who are 20 light years ahead of most children's theater, are also 20 years old this year. To mark their score of years delighting children in New York and abroad, they are back in town, topping a sackful of first-rate holiday weekend theater for youngsters.

Thanksgiving evening, 1976: Robert Torsney, a white New York City police officer on duty in Brooklyn, fires a fatal shot into the head of a 15-year-old black youth, Randolph Evans. Officer Torsney says the shooting was in self-defense; he charges that the boy pulled a gun.

Jeannette Watson McElvenny, cofounder and co-owner of Books Company, a Madison Avenue bookstore, was married yesterday to Alexander Campbell Sanger, a lawyer with the firm of White Case. Civil Court Judge Charles S. Whitman Jr. performed the ceremony at the New York apartment of Mr. and Mrs. Thomas J. Watson Jr. of Greenwich, Conn., and North Haven, Me., parents of the bride.

Legal fees in class action suits can be based on the total amount of money awarded to all members of the class, even if many members fail to come forward to collect their share of the award, according to a decision yesterday by a Federal appeals court.

MIME is traditionally the silent art. Not only is the artist mute, but a respectful pall of silence seems to hang over his audience. Simon Kudrov, however, is a mime with a difference. His performance on Wednesday at the Nat Horne Theater was greeted by chortles, helpless, giggles, cries of "Ole" and even a little verbal audience participation.

The Federal Aviation Administration yesterday acknowledged several "discrepancies" in control of the jet airliner and the small private plane involved in the Sept. 25 midair collision in San Diego and announced an 11-point program to prevent a similar accident there.

The New York Stock Exchange reported yesterday that short interest rose 3.2 million shares to 42.6 million shares in the month ended Dec. 15. The short interest for the yearearlier level totaled 35.3 million shares.

NAIROBI, Kenya, Dec. 21 (AP)--Tens of millions of desert locusts that have matured in southern Ethiopia and Somalia now threaten to spread destruction there and across northern Kenya, Tanzania, Uganda and the Sudan, the East African Desert Locust Control Organization warned today. Swarms of locusts from the Arabian Peninsula moved into parts of Ethiopia and Somalia earlier this year.

CHAMBER Music at the Y," a popular six-concert subscrip tion series at the 92d Street Y.M.-Y.W.H.A., has followed a frankly traditional course since its inception four seasons ago. Rather than aiming for novelty, Jaime Laredo, the artistic director, is chiefly interested in presenting the masterpieces of chamber literature. However familiar the music, Mr. Laredo believes, superior concert performances remain indispensable.

A three-inch snowfall in much of upper New England has given ski areas in that region muchneeded added cover as the holiday weekend approaches. However, skiing will be available on only limited terrain almost everywhere from the Poconos to the upper regions of Vermont and New Hampshire.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 21--Warren Olney 3d, founder of the Federal Judicial Center and a former director of the Administrative Office of the United States Courts, died yesterday in Berkeley, Calif., after a long illness. He was 76 years old.
DETROIT, Dec. 21 (AP)-- United States manufacturers of motor vehicles will have built a record 12.9 million cars and trucks when production lines shut down Saturday.

A board of inquiry into the crash of a Staten Island ferryboat into the Battery Park seawall on Nov. 7 has recommended that the boat's captain be assigned to shore duty for 40 working days from the date of the accident and his assistant for 35 days. The board also recommended that both be reprimanded.

CLEVELAND, Dec. 21--It ballooned into a nightmare almost overnight. But the fiscal crisis in which this industrial city is locked--one that pushed it into fiscal default last week and threatens to force it into bankruptcy by spring--has been a decade or more in the making.

Lynn D. Salvage, president of the First Women's Bank of New York, told a turbulent annual meeting yesterday that the financially troubled bank was in the process of turning around and defended the current policies that she said were responsible for the bank's making its first profit since it opened its doors in 1975.

ATLANTA, Dec. 21--An Alabama prosecutor asked the Georgia authorities today to extradite Gary Thomas Rowe Jr. on the ground that new evidence would prove that Mr. Rowe murdered a civil rights worker while he was on the payroll of the Federal Bureau of Investigation as its chief spy inside the Ku Klux Klan.

JERUSALEM, Dec. 21--Prime Minister Menachem Begin said today that a meeting in Brussels this weekend by representatives of the United States, Israel and Egypt would not be a resumption of the stalled peace talks, but would serve to determine "how, when and where" future negotiations could be held.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 21--A Federal District Court judge has ruled that the Securities and Exchange Commission cannot compel an Iranian sales agent, wanted in connection with the agency's investigation of payments by Textron Inc., to come to the United States and testify.

MOSCOW, Dec. 21 (AP)--A Soviet spacecraft landed on Venus today and radioed back nearly two hours of information on the searing atmosphere of the planet nearest the Earth before going silent in the intense heat, Tass, the Soviet press agency, reported.

The Associated Dry Goods Corporation, one of America's oldest and once one of its most profitable departmentstore chains, is seeking to shift some of its traditional carriage-trade appeal toward attracting the younger and more contemporary-minded customer.

ANGLET, France, Dec. 21 (UPI)--A bomb killed the Basque guerrilla leader Jose Maria Benaran Ordenana today, five years and a day after he allegedly detonated the explosion that took the life of Prime Minister Luis Carrero Blanco of Spain.

Governor Carey and Mayor Koch will ask the Federal Highway Administration to let New York City trade in $270 million earmarked for rebuilding the Long Island Expressway in Queens and use the money instead for mass transit, bridge repair and smaller highway improvements, it was learned yesterday.

The Carrier Corporation, which up to now had been opposing a $1 billion takeover by the United Technologies Corporation, said yesterday that it had decided to begin negotiations with United on a tax-free merger.

NASHVILLE, Dec. 22--Gov. Ray Blanton of Tennessee spent two hours before a Federal grand jury today answering questions about an extortion scandal and later denied any wrongdoing on his part in the alleged sale of executive clemency by his aides.

LEXINGTON, Ky., Dec. 22 (AP)-- Rob Judson sank four free throws in the final 20 seconds tonight, as undefeated Illinois upset Syracuse, 64-61, in the first round of the University of Kentucky invitation tournament. In the second game, the host Wildcats were stunned by Texas A M, 73-69. The Aggies will meet Illinois in the final tomorrow night.

GENEVA, Dec. 22--The United States and the European Economic Community announced today that they had made "significant progress" toward overall agreement on the broad array of measures under discussion here in the Tokyo Round of trade talks involving 99 nations.

Yields rose yesterday in the Treasury's latest sale of three-month and sixmonth bills, climbing to their highest levels since Aug. 26, 1974, when they hit their most generous levels on record.

TOKYO, Dec. 22 (Reuters)--The Toyota Motor Company, Japan's largest vehicle manufacturer, predicted today that its exports next year would drop by about 4 percent.

The United University Professions won the right in an election yesterday to continue representing faculty members and nonteaching professionals on 32 campuses of the State University of New York.

Dickey broke his leg Nov. 13, 1977, in a game against the Los Angeles Rams at Milwaukee County Stadium. He sat out the remainder of last season and this season.

UNITED NATIONS, N.Y., Dec. 23-- Although the 33d General Assembly passed a record 231 resolutions before it recessed on Thursday, it was in the opinion of many diplomats here a disappointing session that illustrated the need for reforms.

One of the longer operatic eras came to an end a week ago Wednesday, when the New York City Opera announced that Beverly Sills would replace Julius Rudel as the company's director. In case you missed the news, Mr. Rudel has announced that he wants to concentrate on his conducting career. He will remain with the New York City Opera until June 30, 1979, after which Miss Sills will assume, her new duties.

AKRON, Ohio, Dec. 23--The General Tire Company plans to replace its aging Akron truck tire plant with a new production facility, either here or in the South. The choice depends on whether the union local accepts a pay reduction and changes in work rule that the company says are needed to make a factory in the North profitable.

CHICAGO, Dec. 22 (UPI)--An X-ray system has reportedly been developed that helps physicians to diagnose cases of child abuse and also halves radiation exposure to patients.

CANTON, Dec. 23--The Chinese Communist Party has pledged to devote itself largely to economic development beginning next year and has expanded its ruling Politburo with the addition of four members associated with the moderate wing, it was announced today.

LAKE HAVASU CITY, Ariz., Dec. 23 (AP)--Charles Dederich, the founder of Synanon, will spend Christmas under arrest at his home because he is too ill to be jailed on charges of instigating a rattlesnake attack, two doctors say.

Dr. Charles J. Fish, founder of the Graduate School of Oceanography at the University of Rhode Island and an American pioneer in marine biology, died Friday at the South County Hospital in Wakefield, R.I., after a long illness. He was 79 years old and lived in West Kingston, R.I.
